p: Friedreich’s ataxia (FRDA) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the abnormal expansion of GAA repeats contributing to suppressed expression of frataxin (FXN) protein [ 84]. Evidence shows that frataxin deficiency in FRDA impairs the intracellular antioxidant defence system, resulting in decreased GSH levels [ 85– 87] and expressions of antioxidant enzymes including SOD, CAT, glutaredoxin, and thioredoxin [ 88]. Additionally, excessive ROS is generated by an iron-dependent Fenton reaction and mitochondrial dysfunction. The compromised antioxidant defence system and ROS accumulation contribute to the unregulated increase in oxidative damage, leading to DNA damage and cell death [ 89– 92].
